Issues.Title: Form and CheckedListBox icons contain only 16x16 frames
Issues.Body:
We need icons with multiple resolution to support HDPI environment. 
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/Resources/System/Windows/Forms/Form.ico
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/Resources/System/Windows/Forms/CheckedListBox.ico
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15823268/109053876-0c623e80-7692-11eb-973f-bc4994aa8778.png)

 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15823268/109053525-a4abf380-7691-11eb-985b-9b570d6fb797.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15823268/109053566-b2fa0f80-7691-11eb-9331-39a818d42078.png)

Ported from 
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms-designer/issues/2904
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms-designer/issues/2905
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Form and CheckedListBox icons contain only 16x16 frames" (#4598)

Issues.Title: DataGridView.SelectedCells returns inconsistent results based on selection type
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
Any version

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**Problem description:**
When using DataGridView.SelectedCells property it returns the Selected Cells. When doing so it ignores the cells from rows which are set Visible = false. i.e. SelectedCells.Count ignores the hidden rows and gets the actual visible cell count

Bug: This however doesn't work if you use rectangular selection. i.e. The selection must include more than 1 column and more than 1 row. In this case the SelectedCells include all the cells from top left to bottom right corners, even from the rows which are set to Visible = false. This is a Inconsistent behavior.

**Expected behavior:**
DatagridView.SelectedCells property should behave the same no matter the selection type. Whether the selection is from the same column or same row or rectangular selection.

**Minimal repro:**
Any Datagridview produces this result
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "DataGridView.SelectedCells returns inconsistent results based on selection type" (#4594)

Issues.Title: The default value is not displayed in the correct position after setting SelectedObject property for PropertyGird control
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: .Net SDK 6.0.100-preview.2.21120.3, .Net SDK 5.0.104 from March 2021 Update Test Pass

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Problem description:**
The default value is not displayed in the correct position after setting SelectedObject property for PropertyGird control. It seems to be displayed in the upper left corner of the propertygrid.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864649/108816650-81316c00-75f1-11eb-8acf-606c391b87d7.png)
![step1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864649/108818313-24838080-75f4-11eb-9558-d09cb32590ea.gif)

**Expected behavior:**
After setting the SelectedObject property for the PropertyGird control, it should display correct default values.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864649/108818177-faca5980-75f3-11eb-86c2-e69ca43bd755.png)

**More Info:**
This is a regression issue, it cannot reproduce on .Net SDK 5.0.103 and .Net SDK 6.0.100-preview.2.21111.1, but can reproduce on **.Net SDK 5.0.104 from March 2021 Update Test Pass and .Net SDK 6.0.100-preview.2.21112.1**.

**Minimal repro:**

1. Create a WinForms .Net Core application.
2. Add a PropertyGird control to Form.
3. Press F4 to go to the Property Browser Window, set its SelectedObject property to Form1.
4. Build and run the application, observe the PropertyGrid.

Or

1. Extract the attached project and open it.
[Test.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6027544/Test.zip)

2. Build and run this application, observe the PropertyGrid.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The default value is not displayed in the correct position after setting SelectedObject property for PropertyGird control" (#4593)

Issues.Title: WinForms designer debugging is not working for netcore app
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
NetCore 3.1 and recent version

VS: VS2019

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Problem description:**

I trying to do designer debugging for my WinForms net core application using devenv.exe, but the breakpoint is never hit the source. Is designer debugging working in NETCore application.


**Expected behavior:**
The WinForms designer debugging should work.



**Minimal repro:**
Steps to reproduce:

1. In the attached project, I have created a custom button control with Property Called MyText.

2. Open the project setting and Select the Debug tab.

3. Choose the Launch Executables option. ---> Note: In Framework, it will display as Start with External Program.

4. Choose devenv exe location as the executable path.

5. Then Put the breakpoint in the MyText property setter of CustomButton class.

6. Then Click start program to start debugging.

7. Then click the WinformformsApp1 in the recent list.

8. Open the Form1 designer in the newly open VS instance.

10. Then Change MyText property value in design time.

11.Now the Setter of MyText property should be hit while changing its value. But breakpoint won't hit.

The Same scenario working fine in the 4.6 or less Framework application.

**Project:** 
[169259-windowsformsapp1-copy.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6006962/169259-windowsformsapp1-copy.zip)


**Reproducible Video:** 
[169273-debugvideo.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6006964/169273-debugvideo.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WinForms designer debugging is not working for netcore app" (#4583)

Issues.Title: ComboBox does not handle DataBindings and empty BindingLists
Issues.Body:
* .NET Framwork Version: 
.NET Framework 4.7.2

**Problem description:**
Problem 1:
If a BindingList is set as the DataSource for a default ComboBox and the BindingList is/gets empty,
on adding Items to the BindingList neither events (SelectedIndexChanged) are fired nor any
additional DataBindings are taken care of.

Problem 2:
DataBindings generally need the WriteValue() function called from the SelectionChangeCommitted event
in order to get set from the GUI ComboBox, which is an unnecessary workaround.

**Expected behavior:**
I set a empty BindingList as DataSource for the ComboBox and setup additional Databindings.
When adding an item to the empty BindingList the SelectedItemChanged, TextUpdate, SelectedIndexChanged
and SelectedValueChanged events of the ComboBox should fire and all associated DataBindings should get
updated/set (e.g. SelectedItem).
Selecting an item via GUI should update/set associated DataBinding without additional
function calls from events.

**Minimal repro:**
https://github.com/KingMetal7/ComboBox_Bug.git
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ComboBox does not handle DataBindings and empty BindingLists" (#4582)

Issues.Title: Control Arrays in Design Mode
Issues.Body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

I'd like to see a similar solution to the one implemented in VB6 for Control Arrays in Design Mode. When can this be useful? When you have complex cases like this one:

[![Many labels in a window form][2]][2]

I had over 500 pictures that handled an Odontogram. This case was impossible to migrate to .NET because it would have involved a considerable re-engineering process from my side. Also, I believe a similar feature could be brought to **MAUI, WPF, and Avalonia**. This would increase the flexibility when you have to handle multiple related controls.

**Describe the solution you'd like and alternatives you've considered**

After reading several forums over the years, I was able to write this piece of code that more or less fixed "the problem" of Control Arrays in Design Mode. The example uses a series of **Label controls** created in Design Mode.

[![Many labels in a window form][1]][1]

### Code examples:

**VB.NET:**

```vb
Public Class Form1

    'To declare the List of controls
    Dim labels As New List(Of Label)()

    Private Sub Form1_Load(sender As Object, e As EventArgs) Handles MyBase.Load
        'To get all controls in the form
        For Each control In Me.Controls
            'To search for the specific type that you want to create the array 
            If control.[GetType]().Name.Contains("Label") Then
                'To add the control to the List
                labels.Add(DirectCast(control, Label))
            End If
        Next
        'To sort the labels by the ID
        labels = labels.OrderBy(Function(x) x.Name).ToList()
    End Sub
End Class
```

**C#:**

```csharp
public class Form1
{

    // To declare the List of controls
    private List<Label> labels = new List<Label>();

    private void Form1_Load(object sender, EventArgs e)
    {
        // To get all controls in the form
        foreach (var control in this.Controls)
        {
            // To search for the specific type that you want to create the array 
            if (control.GetType().Name.Contains("Label"))
                // To add the control to the List
                labels.Add((Label)control);
        }
        // To sort the labels by the ID
        labels = labels.OrderBy(x => x.Name).ToList();
    }
}
```

I used a **List** for convenient reasons, but with the pieces of code I shared, anyone can create in design time the controls that they need, and while they keep the "index" as the last character (label**1**, label**2**, ..., label**N**).

Later, they can iterate them with the loop and add them in the blink of an eye. After, they can manipulate them from the object (labels) like before labels(0), labels(1), etc.

There are 3 points to take into consideration:

 1. A `List` can be used to emulate the large collection of controls.
 2. `typeof(Control)` helps us define the type of the control to add to the list.
 3. The **"index"** defined as the last character *(label**1**, label**2**, ..., label**N**)* is the key. This helps us create a logical order.

Furthermore, here is another example running created **design mode** using **Text Boxes**:

[![Many text boxes in one window][3]][3]

**Running:**

[![running example][4]][4]

  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/a2NLj.png
  [2]: https://mir-s3-cdn-cf.behance.net/project_modules/max_1200/3624de11048267.560f05aecb9e9.jpg
  [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/uyCjW.png
  [4]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/atES2.png
**Will this feature affect UI controls?**

Up to a certain point. It might need a new property called Index or something that relates to this feature. I'd say a similar code to the one I shared can be used in the background. Also, another property might be needed to identify if it's an array.

Form1.cs
```cs
using System;

{
    public partial class Form1 : Form
    {
        public Form1()
        {
            InitializeComponent();
            Console.WriteLine("TEST");    // Add only this line.
        }

    }
}
```

**Expected behavior:**

- `TEST` is output to `OUTPUT`. (Like .Net Framework Forms app)

Please tell me how to output string to `OUTPUT`.

**Minimal repro:**

1. use Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2019 Version 16.8.5
1. Create `Windows Forms App(.NET)`
1. Add only `Console.WriteLine("TEST");`
